Odd One Out
Confusion
The Road Taken
End Of The Road
Pure Freedom
The Floating World
Where The Wild Wind Blows
Ask Me Where I'm A Local

The Exiled And Forgotten
Moving Up In The World
NA
Above The Clouds
Castle In The Sky
The Entrusted
Finally
All There Is
Love
Where One Story Ends
Now where should we begin?
At the beginning? Like, the very beginning? When Tessa created the world?
No, that's a bit too far back.
Instead, we'll begin where many stories begin, with a character.
Ball.
He was abandoned. Left to us in the dead of night. His parents gone.
Typical of Circles, you know. No responsibility.
So we took him in and raised him.
For years, we gave him everything our wonderful society had to offer.
A loving foster family. A school. A good life.
And how did he repay us? Did he become a productive member of society?
No!
He disappeared!
Ball left Los Angles suddenly. Didn't come to school one day.
Wasn't content, for whatever reason.
Ball bounced his way out. No obstacle could stop him.
He could scale many walls. A cube skill, but one Ball learned to fit in.
For all the good that did.
Ball had only one thing on his tiny, stupid mind. To leave. To run away.
Ah, the Hidden Shape. I was surprised Ball found it. He never struck me as all that clever.
But the real question is why. It didn't make sense.
Cubes built this paradise, and yet Ball wanted nothing to do with it.
Maybe that was it. Raised by cubes, yes. But Ball was never really one of us.
He always stood out. It wasn't just his appearance. He made himself stand out.
Even with all of our help, Ball was never good at fitting in.
Well, no use questioning the motives of a madman. There are far more productive ways to spend my time.
I thought that shape was hidden pretty well. I suppose I could be wrong, once in a while.
I'm glad he left, you know. All he ever did was burden us.
Go on, Ball. Get out of here. Never return.
Nobody wanted you. Nobody liked you.
Los Angles was a city for Cubes anyway. Not some Circle like you.
*ahem* Sorry, I was just talking to myself.
Those dirty Circles who left Ball on our doorstop. Who pushed their burden on us.
You know, it was never his home anyway. He didn't belong here.
In fact, I suppose it was a favor of his, in some way. Leaving.
Where was Ball going, you ask?
Have you heard of Pyramid?
Land of the Triangles. Home of the laziest shapes you've ever met.
All talk, no action, those ones. Knowledge first, work second.
Why Ball sought them out, I'll never know.
But there he went. Gone. Never to return.
Thank Tessa, he's gone!
Ball would receive help no longer. He was on his own.
It was admittedly impressive. To find this hidden shape. Or perhaps just lucky.
The road was ending, and with it, the end of Ball's subjugation.
It was the cubes that had made life difficult for Ball. Their rules and attitudes had been the prime force keeping Ball down.
How Ball managed to break free of those bonds, I'll never know.
But, I'm glad it happened.
Oh, me?
My name is Simone Plex. Call me "Sim".
I'm a teacher in Pyramid. And one, of many, who showed Ball the way.
Though there are no rulebooks for wandering journeys.
The Eastern Road of Los Angles was abandoned mid-construction. It's atypical. Cubes tend to follow through with their actions.
Yet their society has become ever more insular. Closing up in order to curb the randomness of the outside world.
Ball made her way to the desert, steadfast, unperturbed by the situation she found herself in.
Why do I say "her" and "she" instead of "him" and "he"? Well who was the one saying those things?
It doesn't really matter what words you use for Ball's gender. Shapes don't have distinctions for these things.
Use whatever word you want. I'll follow the same policy. I don't think Ball will mind either way.
Ball worried about her decision. Was it a good idea to leave the city? She had never been out of that cage.
True, the desert was wonderful. A first. But so was the lack of direction.
This freedom made Ball... faster. Every time Ball stopped, she slowed. But when she began moving, nothing could slow her down.
Ball found an object often referred to as a Hidden Shape.
But this freedom became suffocating for Ball.
After all the rules and hard lines of Cube society, Ball felt that being out here was wrong.
Where to go? What to do?
These things had been defined in Los Angles. Order was not questioned, only assumed.
And now, without order, with pure freedom, Ball found that her old life was calling her. Asking her what she was doing here. In this land of nothing, without borders.
Ball panicked and realized that she didn't know where she was.
It was then that Ball saw Pyramid in the distance.
Ball happened upon what looked like the road leading to Pyramid, and followed it.
And there it stood, like a star, guiding her.
Pyramid. One of the wonders of the world, if such categorization benefits your understanding.
To us Tetras, this place is home. Cubes have their Los Angles, while we have Pyramid.
I waited for Ball on the second ring.
I was glad to be able to introduce this wonder to Ball.
Ball was very inquisitive, and seemed eager to learn.
Pyramid is a rather ancient city. It began construction more than four millennia ago.
It's in fact the oldest Pyra, which explains why it isn't suspended entirely in the air.
Depending on your sources, you may come across information stating that our Pyralower is even older.
But, I think you'll find that the evidence doesn't support that theory.
Though I... dare not rule it out.
The eastern side of Pyramid served as the gathering and living spaces for tetras. Here was a place for socializing and learning.

Tetras often came to Pyramid to seek knowledge. While Pyraupper is more of a government city, Pyramid is here for those who wish to spend their time understanding the essence of the world, rather than rule over it.
Those in Los Angles miscategorize our behavior out here as lethargic. As if all Tetras sit around and do nothing.
On the contrary, we spent a great deal of time disseminating the facts of the world.
Even if thinking is somehow… “doing nothing”… Were cubes to see the Tetras toiling away in Pyralower, I think they'd choke on their own misguided views.
Ball had some difficulty traversing the space. These weren't the simple roads of Los Angles.
Suspended, moving platforms had been necessary due to the rarity of lemonstone.
Lemonstone being the main building material for Pyramid.
The ancient Tetras nearly exhausted their supply erecting the central body.
So, with their remaining supply, they built smaller platforms to transport passengers longer distances, thereby needing fewer blocks of lemonstone to complete the passageways.
Today, lemonstone can be synthesized with ease. But the legacy of that scarcity remains in this city's architecture.
Some of the platforms were in dire need of repair, of course, and were of no use to anyone.
But as most Tetras knew how to float, it wasn't a huge problem.
That, and few Tetras want to bother with repairs. No sense wasting time with that when there were new things to discover.
The western side of Pyramid once served as something of an energy-production factory.
The constant motion of the platforms generated a large amount of power, able to light the place during the dark period.
One of my colleagues believes this has something to do with... magnets. I'm not entirely aware myself.
Magnets. How do they work?
Best return to my studies.
This path around the back was actually constructed as a collaborative effort with cubes a few centuries ago, when Los Angles was still but a small village.
Back in those days, cubes came to visit often.
Nowadays, not so much.
They seem more content building their city higher and higher rather than coming here to learn.
Seeing Ball struggle, I attempted to teach her how to float.
We had a good time together, Ball and I. Would have befitted a montage.
The way Ball learned, well, it was different than that of a Tetra. She asked more questions. She expected me to know more than I did. I could tell she was frustrated.
But there was a glimmer in her eye. Hope? Perhaps because failure was not looked down upon quite so harshly here. I'm not sure.
With her newfound knowledge of floating, Ball could access the top of Pyramid without much trouble.
Ball was glad to be able to float. Yet I was honestly shocked at how quickly Ball learned.
Few spheres could pick up an ability so quickly.
Traditional knowledge says that floating was something unique to Tetras.
Modern knowledge notes that other shapes can learn to float, but that their ability can't approach a Tetra's.
Seeing Ball, however, made me return to my studies. Perhaps there was more to this than we knew.
I met Ball again at the top.
Ball mentioned that she was looking for her parents. I, of course, had no knowledge on this subject.
However, there was one who may know the answer.
The Entrusted. The leader of the Tetras. Seer and knower of all.
But the Entrusted resided in Pyraupper, and that could be a difficult journey for a non-Tetra.
Ball needed to make her way through the Rolling Plains, up the Prettyhigh Steppe, and then across the Suspended Bridge, where one fall could spell doom.
This didn't seem to dissuade Ball. The knowledge that someone out there could help seemed to brighten her mood, though I couldn't say for sure.
I said goodbye to Ball, content with what I'd learned.
Broken pathways lay strewn about the ground. They've been there since I was but a child.
You don't think much about your surroundings until strangers comment.
Tetras often came here to dance. Disco. Boogie. Waltz.
I'm pretty good at line dancing myself. It's a style in which you jump up and down on a line. Very fun.
Don't get me started on square dancing though.
What a load of trash.
These red objects were once active. Sometimes all it takes is a small collision to get them going again.
The red jets could toss someone skyward. Once activated, of course.
Ah, some jets. Waiting to be made active.
Tetras had no need for these machines. But, perhaps Ball could find some use.
The invisible path. I'm surprised Ball found it. Then again, that sphere was always full of secrets.
Ball could roll around in the desert for hours. I never understood what she enjoyed so much about it.
Ball often seemed preoccupied with the collection of hidden shapes. Perhaps sphere minds are different like that.
Ah, Ball. Yeah, I 'member when 'e came here. Wasn't too long ago.
Came from th' east. From the triangle desert.
Hard t' miss 'im. Th' way 'e resisted th' wind.
Ya c'n call me Marui. I'm a sphere from th' Rollin' Plains. It's my home, I s'pose. Lived here my whole life.
Been t' th' Longtimeno Sea once. Saw a friend off. 'Ts 'bout it.
Else I been here. Where the wind blows.
Ball? Yeah, what abou'im?
Ya wanna know what 'e thought abou'us?
He was… cor-di-al. From a distance, anyways.
He ain't never spit on no one, but he didn't want ta make friends, ya know?
Ball fell inta th' tar pits once or twice, I hear. On the way over. Don't know 'ow 'e got outta 'em.
Perseverance? Guess tha' cou'a done it.
I guess Ball found a Hidden Shape on 'is way. Fine with me that 'e takes it, ya know?
Th' white winds brough' him here. T' th' sphere homeland.
Not for all tha' long. Just long enough.
Apparently was makin' a journey to the northern mountains.
No reason to go there.
No reason not to go either, I s'pose.
Th' blue object was one of our neeto-things. Tha "Henshok".
Switched yer color around.
Blue ones t' blue.
Red ones t' red.
We had lots of them, so, ya know, Ball could use 'em as 'e pleased.
Word came around quick abou' tha' Ball. 'E moved funny. Said things tha' ya never 'ear said.
E had this… uh… look on his face. Like 'e ain't never seen 'nother sphere b'fore.
But we welcomed 'im nonetheless. Seemed nice as 'e was odd.
He would roam with a little more speed an' direction than we were used ta.
Sure, spheres're roamers. But we ain't usually roamin' with such intensity.
Slow down. Smell the grass. Savor th' wind on yer sides, ya know?
Bargin' in on homes. Stayin' fer a second, then leavin'.
E was free to go as 'e wished, but 'e didn't even seem like 'e knew where 'e was goin'!
Well, who am I ta judge?
I didn't see it firsthand or nothin', but word got 'round that Ball was... abrasive, ya know? Seem like 'e's always lookin' fer a fight.
Mean little guy, from tha sound of it. Maybe it's jus' 'e was young. Brash. Takin' on th' world.
I ain't see what everyone was sayin'. Not front of my eyes. But rumors ain't based off nothin', ya know?
I dunno why Ball kept lookin' at that goddamned wall. He seemed totally in love with it.
Didn't 'e understand how much we hated it? Goddamn thing running right through these beautiful lands.
I dunno what 'e was thinkin'.
Was 'e a spy? That why you askin'?
No? You dunno?
Fair enough.
I tell you what I hear, what I see, but honestly, I got no clue why 'e came here.
Th' Ring stood in th' middle. Th' "Wa".
Our symbol, of sorts.
Not something t'bow down ta, like Los Angles's "Exton Buildin'". Just something t'know where ya are and where ya've come from.
Ball didn't know what t' make of it. So 'e decided to climb it, jus' like a damn square.
There was nothin' out here. Which is fine with us. More freedom to do with as we please.
A lot of folks consider openness boring. City-folk often say, "I need somethin' ta do!
But I say, stop a moment. See what life is like before ya knock it.
Ball didn't want to stop though. Had places to be, I s'pose.
We 'ave a sayin', "every sphere is unique". Tha' extends t' their humble abodes.
This sphere was a minimalist. Likes keepin' things small, ya know.
This sphere's house was two layers. Top an' bottom. Prolly t' keep those in-laws out, amirite?
Some folks liked uniformity. That's more of a square thing, but eh.
Honestly prolly what Ball's house'd look like.
This is a weird one. But who am I to cast judgment?
Well, I'll be. Completely hollow. What's with that? Guess they're movin' or somethin'.
This sphere didn't like platforms. Wanted everythin' sphere-like.
Whoever kept this house put everythin' on the outside.
Who's t' say that's not the best way to live?
Jus' won't see me doing that, ya hear?
At th' top, 'e could see the beauty around 'im. Th' mist and th' clouds were nothin'.
And 'e saw what he came fer. A path. T'th'north.
HS: Ball searched far an' wide fer dem hidden shapes. What was 'e usin' 'em fer? Trophies?
E left th' Rollin' Plains. Foun' th' Steppe, it seemed.
Ya know, wor' on th' grapevine was tha' Ball was from Los Angles. That damned eyesore of a city.
Th' rumor, if y'll hear it, was that Ball witnessed a su-i-cide. A Cube tha' killed 'imself.
Failed too many times and lost 'is job 'r somethin'. Not sure.
But Ball saw it. Right in front of 'im.
So 'e left. Didn' wan' tha' life fer 'imself.
Don' blame 'im.
In spite o' everythin', gotta say I was sad fer 'im. Ball didn' 'ave nothin' more than a direction.
No home. No family. No friends.
All alone, out here.
And with 'is attitude, I think it'll stay tha' way.
E gets in th' way of 'imself, ya know?
Sometimes I wonder if we were too hard on 'im.
Like, we see a Tetra, we gawk. Always a little impressive to see 'em flyin' an' such.
A square come here, usually ignored, ya know? Don't wanna mess with 'em.
A sphere, well, we know all 'em. It was a surprise ta see one we don't know. Didn't really know what ta do.
End of th' day, in retrospect, I think we were a little cruel to 'im.
But didn't stop 'im any. Resolute little guy.
He jus' kep' goin'. Off ta th' Steppe.
HS: Some say our god Glome put these shapes up 'ere. No idea why though.
Ball wandered for some time until he wound up here.
The Prettyhigh Steppe lay at the end of the Northern Road.
Ball came to us in search of a way.
Looking for Pyraupper. Odd request. Most everyone who wanted to go there already knew how.
I knew, when I first met Ball, that he was like me. Outcast. Couldn't fit in.
That's what we all were, up here. The ones who couldn't make it in that city.
Most of us, anyway. Shikaku's family had been here since before Los Angles was built up. Glad he stayed.
My name is Rhom. I'm one of Paulie's oldest friends. A mentor, of sorts, actually.
Who's Paulie?
Paulie Hedron?
You know. The one who let Ball out. The president of Los Angles.
Paulie's not a bad cube. He means well.
Then again, most everyone means well, after the fact.
Paulie just had a habit of not understanding the perspective of others.
He saw Ball as particularly unsympathetic. That a sphere would have trouble in Los Angles and complain about it... Paulie couldn't quite grasp it.
We too, those of us out here, had trouble in Los Angles. Yet for some reason, Paulie holds little resent for us.
The red mountains were steep. Ball could climb them, but it wasn't easy.
Or, maybe it wasn't too bad for Ball. He didn't seem to struggle like most circles do.
Sorry, spheres. Not circles. My bad. Habit, you know.
Tetras lived up here too. While most tetras lived in one of the Pyras, this area was somewhat popular as well.
There was equality here. No hierarchy.
Everyone had a similar house. A roof over their head.
The locations were different, but just that. Different, not better nor worse.
Cubes came here to rid themselves of the culture of Los Angles. The hurt. The blame. The need to work. The shame that came with poor performance.
This place was no paradise... but it didn't seek to be.
Tetras came here to get a taste of cube society. See if they could learn something or other.
Most tetras said they wouldn't dare go to that monument to cube consumerism and law and order.
But all I see is a bunch of triangles that can't stand the thought that they're not on top.
S-sorry, tetras. Not triangles. I'm better than that.
I'd be lying if I said that everyone chose to be here.
Though many come of their own volition, others... Well, we have some criminals among us.
Petty crime, but, crime nonetheless.
Sometimes political rivals get sent out here too. We take them with open arms, but they're usually not so glad to see us.
Guess Ball probably understands, though his circumstances differed.
Ball explored the village, little by little. He seemed shocked that shapes would offer a "hello" or "howdy doo".
Perhaps our quaint towns were a little much for him.
Ball said to me once that he was surprised the Prettyhigh Steppe was so built up. He thought this was just a road to pass through.
In all his time in Los Angles, he never imagined there was anything over here.
He wasn't intending to stay here long. Made sense. He still had places to go. People to see.
But he'd be back, someday. I knew he'd take a liking to here.
These odd floating shapes appeared occasionally. Who put them here? Not that we don't welcome them, of course.
Arrows. A path. Ball moved onward.
The arrow is part triangle, part square. Ever notice?
Without the square, the triangle could point anywhere. Useless.
Without the triangle, the square has no direction. Also useless.
Yet, working together, they make a quite functional symbol.
I'm not much for metaphor, but there's something there.
You know, there is value in taking the common path. The road often traveled.
Knowledge of those that came before you. For your benefit.
This road is well-documented, if perhaps a little roundabout.
Safe, but boring.
But safe, nevertheless.
I was always taught that Tetras were slackers. Smart, well-intentioned, slackers.
And then I met one. Two. Five. Ten.
And they were slackers, by my old standards. They were smart, but they never used their knowledge. I couldn't get it.
I still don't understand their thought-process, not fully. But I do understand that they aren't the lazy shapes we imagined.
Just because they weren't using their information to construct, as we might have, doesn't mean they weren't using it.
Avoiding the wisdom of your elders. There is value in that road as well.
It can be quicker to the top. In fact, it often is.
But that path, the new one, the untrodden one... is fraught with peril.
And the fall, the setback, is far more dangerous.
Yet to dissuade someone from making a new path is foolhardy for a species. I wouldn't dare.
I liked Ball. Wish he'd like me. But you really can't control others.
Why are you curious about Ball?
Because he's different?
Everyone's different. But it's hard to see that, sometimes.
Anyway, you've heard enough from me. Go talk to that one. He knows more about that whole side of Ball's trip.
You want to find something? Discover something new? Then the odd road is the only place for you.
Sorry, didn't mean for that to rhyme.
